results.title: When Helpless Fish Need a Hero, She Answers the Call
results.abstract: Three hundred goldfish in a hospital basement, a suckermouth at the airport: When fish are in crisis, a Bronx beautician and a partner in Pennsylvania ride to the rescue.
org_facet: Animal Care and Control of New York City

media.caption: Brenda Prohaska, seen here at her home in the Bronx, has undertaken about 90 fish rescues in the past several years, saving the lives of abandoned fish all over New York City.

results.abstract: It can be hard to reconcile the need for close connections with the urge to cancel plans. Experts say it’s a matter of taking control and finding your comfort zone.

results.title: Her Doctor Said Her Illness Was All in Her Head. This Scientist Was Determined to Find the Truth.
results.abstract: After enduring severe nausea and vomiting in pregnancy, the geneticist Marlena Fejzo made finding the cause of her condition, hyperemesis gravidarum, her life’s work.

media.caption: Hyperemesis gravidarum, a pregnancy condition marked by nausea and vomiting so severe it can cause catastrophic complications for mother and fetus, has long been under-researched and insufficiently recognized.
media.copyright: Maggie Shannon for The New York Times

results.title: Residents’ Right to Be Rude Upheld by Massachusetts Supreme Court
results.abstract: In an age of division, the court ruled that towns could not mandate polite discourse at public meetings. One official called the decision “very dispiriting.”

media.caption: Louise Barron and her husband, Jack, filed a lawsuit after she was threatened with removal from a Southborough Select Board meeting in December 2018 for criticizing the board.

results.title: Lyme Isn’t the Only Tick Disease to Worry About in the Northeast, C.D.C Says
results.abstract: Babesiosis, which can cause flulike symptoms, could be spreading because of rising temperatures and the growing deer population.

media.caption: The blacklegged-tick-borne disease babesiosis, which for decades was extremely rare in the United States, is now endemic in 10 states in the Northeast and the Midwest.
media.copyright: Centers for Disease Control, via Associated Press

results.title: Kehinde Wiley’s New Exhibition Is a Chapel for Mourning
results.abstract: “An Archaeology of Silence” opens in San Francisco, after a string of police killings of Black men. Along with powerful art, it offers a respite room to those needing a break.
org_facet: de Young, M H, Memorial Museum
Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco

media.caption: Kehinde Wiley at “An Archaeology of Silence” at the de Young Museum in San Francisco with his monumental 2022 painting, “Femme piquée par un serpent (Mamadou Gueye).” Works were made in response to the killings of Black men and women — “bodies chopped down,” the artist said. This one nods to an 1847 sculpture “Woman Bitten by a Serpent” by Auguste Clésinger.
media.copyright: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times
